reference.shortdesc: A link title is an alternative title for a resource to be used with references to the resource that do not otherwise specify text for display.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: Link titles are alternative titles for use in cases where a hyperlink or cross-reference to a resource has no text explicitly authored. This includes, but is not limited to, the following cases.

ul.li: Manually-authored link elements that do not specify a linktext element.
Generated link elements based on a map structure or relationship table.
Navigation link when no titlealt with a title-role of navigation is present, such as navtitle.
Search result links when no titlealt with a title-role of search is present, such as searchtitle.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: The linktitle element is a specialization of titlealt with the title-role set to linking. Processing is dictated by the rules for titlealt.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The linktitle element is specialized from titlealt. It is defined in the alternativeTitle-domain module.

section.title: Attributes
section.p: The following attributes are available on this element: , class, outputclass, and the title-role attribute set to linking.

example.title: Examples
example.p: This section contains examples of how the linktitle element can be used.

fig.title: Link title within a map
fig.p: The following code sample shows how a linktitle element can be used within a topicref to provide text for a related link to a non-DITA resource:
fig.codeblock: <topicref href="SQLJ-example.html" format="html" scope="local"> <topicmeta> <linktitle>Accessing relational data with SQLJ</linktitle> </topicmeta> </topicref>

fig.title: Link title within a topic
fig.p: The following code sample shows how a linktitle element can be used within a topic's prolog to provide default text for use in cross-references, rather than using the topic's title.
fig.codeblock: <topic id="topic"> <title>Circuitry in the C-283 Drive Train</title> <prolog> <linktitle>Drive Train Circuitry</linktitle> </prolog>
